hawaiian_text: 'Ī aku 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Ua 'ike au, he kanaka nui nō 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o, a ua hele aku nei ma Ko'olau, a 'o wau he inoa nona." 'Ī mai lākou: "'A'ole, 'o 'oe nō, pela ko makou lohe, no laila, e make ana 'oe iā mākou, 'a'ole 'oe e ola." 'Ī aku 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Ho'i aku ho'i hā kākou i lalo e hakakā ai." A hiki lākou i lalo, e hao aku ana 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o, pau loa i ka make, a koe aku ho'okahi kanaka, 'o ia ka i holo aku ā loa'a 'o 'Ama'u ma Waikīkī, 'ōlelo akula ia i ka make o lākou a pau loa, a koe ia i 'āha'ilono e lohe ai 'o 'Ama'u.
llama-3.3-70B-Instruct_exl2_6.0bpw-maui_: Nāmakaokapāo'o said: "I know, I, Nāmakaokapāo'o, am a great person, and I have gone to Ko'olau, and I am famous." They said: "No, it is you, as we have heard, therefore, you will die by our hands, you will not live." Nāmakaokapāo'o said: "Let us go down and struggle." When they went down, Nāmakaokapāo'o began to destroy, and all were killed, except for one person, who ran away and arrived at Waikīkī, told 'Ama'u about their complete destruction, and 'Ama'u was informed.

**Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>Nāmakaokapāo'o said: "I know, I, Nāmakaokapāo'o, am a great person, and I have gone to Ko'olau, and I am famous." They said: "No, it is you, as we have heard, therefore, you will die by our hands, you will not live." Nāmakaokapāo'o said: "Let us go down and struggle." When they went down, Nāmakaokapāo'o began to destroy, and all were killed, except for one person, who ran away and arrived at Waikīkī, told 'Ama'u about their complete destruction, and 'Ama'u was informed.</translation>

<commentary>This narrative context marks a turning point in the story of Nāmakaokapāo'o, highlighting his confident assertion of his own greatness and the lethal confrontation that follows.</commentary>

• The passage starts with **Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o** (the eyes of the pāo'o fish) claiming his own greatness, emphasizing his **inoa** (fame, reputation) in **Ko'olau** (a region on the island of O'ahu). This can be seen as a symbol of his growing self-awareness and assertiveness, which is a common theme in Hawaiian mythology.
– The name **Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o** itself is worth analyzing, as **nā maka** (the eyes) might represent insight, wisdom, or spiritual vision, while **o** (of, belonging to) **ka pāo'o** (the pāo'o fish) could signify a connection to the ocean, abundance, or spiritual growth.
• The response from the opposing group, **"'A'ole, 'o 'oe nō, pela ko makou lohe, no laila, e make ana 'oe iā mākou, 'a'ole 'oe e ola"** (No, it is you, as we have heard, therefore, you will die by our hands, you will not live), suggests that they are aware of Nāmakaokapāo'o's reputation and perceive him as a threat, which is reminiscent of the **'Ai Kapu** era's emphasis on the struggle for power and control.
– The phrase **"e make ana 'oe iā mākou"** (you will die by our hands) implies a sense of collective responsibility and communal action, which was a key aspect of Hawaiian society during the **'Ai Kapu** period.
• Nāmakaokapāo'o's suggestion to **"ho'i aku ho'i hā kākou i lalo e hakakā ai"** (go down and struggle) can be seen as a symbol of his willingness to engage in conflict and challenge the status quo, which is a common theme in Hawaiian mythology and history.
– The use of the word **hakakā** (to struggle, to wrestle) might imply a physical or spiritual struggle, highlighting the idea that Nāmakaokapāo'o is not only fighting for his life but also for his identity and purpose.
• The outcome of the struggle, where **"pau loa i ka make"** (all were killed), except for one person who escaped to **Waikīkī** and informed **'Ama'u**, suggests that Nāmakaokapāo'o's actions have significant consequences, leading to the destruction of his opponents and potentially impacting the broader community.
– The name **'Ama'u** might be related to **'ama'u** (to warn, to inform), implying that this character serves as a messenger or a warning sign, which is a common motif in Hawaiian storytelling.
• The final phrase, **"a koe ia i 'āha'ilono e lohe ai 'o 'Ama'u"** (and 'Ama'u was informed), suggests that the events of the story are being communicated and shared, potentially serving as a lesson or a warning to others, which is consistent with the Hawaiian tradition of storytelling as a means of passing on knowledge and cultural values.
reference_translation: Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "I know. Nāmakaokapāo'o is a really big guy. He went to Ko'olau. I'm named after him." The soldiers said, "No, it's you. That's what we heard. So, we're going to kill you. You won't survive." Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "Well, let's go down and fight." When they got down, Nāmakaokapāo'o went to work and killed them all except one man, who ran off and reached 'Ama'u in Waikīkī. He told him about the how they were all killed except for one runner to go and tell 'Ama'u about it.
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14** • From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of Christianity's defeat over the 'Ai Kapu, with Nāmakaokapāo'o representing progressive Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his mother, Pōka'ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians' futile attempts to hold onto 'Ai Kapu culture.
